entry.title: Hosting a remote development server
entry.content:
Intent

We‚Äôll be using code-server, a great initiative by Coder in making the process of self hosting a remote development environment serving Visual Studio Code easy.

You‚Äôll learn how you can host a remote working environment for your project in minutes.

The Why?

Before going ahead the first question everyone will be asking would be ‚ÄúWhy would I need a remote code editor for my project?‚Äù. Well to quote code-server

  • Code on your Chromebook, tablet, and laptop with a consistent dev environment.
    • If you have a Windows or Mac workstation, more easily develop for Linux.
  • Take advantage of large cloud servers to speed up tests, compilations, downloads, and more.
  • Preserve battery life when you‚Äôre on the go.
    • All intensive computation runs on your server.
    • You‚Äôre no longer running excess instances of Chrome.

To simplify, we can harness the processing power of remote machine to run tests and builds without sacrificing performance of your local machine.

Requirements

  • Account on any cloud hosting service like AWS, Azure, GCP
  • Nginx for serving platform on the Web

For this exercise purpose we‚Äôll we using AWS and because I don‚Äôt use any other service üòÇ

  • Boot a new instance with Ubuntu Server 18.04 LTS. You can choose any instance of your choice e.g. t2.micro
  • Make sure you keep port 80 open on this instance, you can open 443 as well for SSL connection.

entry.title: What is InfluxDB?
entry.content:
Just to quote Wiki

InfluxDB is an open-source time series database developed by InfluxData. It is written in Go and optimized for fast, high-availability storage and retrieval of time series data in fields such as operations monitoring, application metrics, Internet of Things sensor data, and real-time analytics.

But before we jump down that rabbit hole, let‚Äôs wrap our heads around what Time Series Databases (TSDB) are ‚Ä¶

Time Series Database

Time Series Database is a database designed specifically to work with time stamped data.

In layman‚Äôs term

A timestamp is your only Primary Key to read a data point.

Note: Going ahead we‚Äôll refer Time Series Database as TSDB. Ok fine I‚Äôm lazy üòÖ

TSDB usage

  • Event tracking, monitoring and aggregate data over time
  • Server metrics
  • Application performance monitoring
  • Network and Sensor data
  • Trades in a market

Few examples of TSDB

  1. Prometheus
  2. OpenTSDB
  3. Graphite
  4. InfluxDB
